Award.AwardTitle: Expanding the Medicago truncatula Hapmap as a Platform for Exploring the Genetics of Legume Symbioses
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Nevin Young (University of Minnesota)

Co-PIs: Michael Sadowsky, Robert Stupar, and Peter Tiffin (University of Minnesota), Maria Harrison (Boyce Thompson Institute for Plant Research), Betsy Martinez-Vaz (Hamline University), Jason Rafe Miller (J. Craig Venter Institute), Joann Mudge (National Center for Genome Resources)

This project uses functional assays, de novo genome assembly and bioinformatic data-mining to characterize symbiosis genes in the model legume Medicago truncatula. Legumes are noteworthy for the sophisticated symbioses they form with rhizobial bacteria and arbuscular mycorrhizal (AM) fungi. However, existing knowledge about symbioses comes primarily from knockout mutants, an approach that often misses genes of subtle yet significant effect, especially genes likely to be important in contemporary evolution. In earlier work, several strongly supported candidate symbiosis loci were discovered through genome-wide association analysis (GWAS) and support for candidate genes often included independent evidence like expression profile, correlation with multiple traits or co-localization with known symbiotic phenotypes. The current project will test ~100 of these candidate loci through reverse genetic experiments involving Tnt1 insertion and RNAi "knockdown" plant lines. Promising genes will be examined through interaction assays involving previously defined Sinorhizobium and AM strains and tested for "gene-for-gene" relationships using a panel of 48 sequenced Sinorhizobium strains. Earlier GWAS mapping only targeted SNP variation, even though structural variants (SVs) and copy number variants (CNVs) are known to have major impacts on genome variation. This is especially relevant to the genomics of symbiosis because the large gene families such as the NB-ARC domain-containing genes and nodule cysteine rich peptides (NCRs) play critical roles in symbiosis. This project will deeply sequence and de novo assemble 30 nodal M. truncatula accessions, in order to discover SVs and CNVs. SVs and CNVs will be imputed genome-wide, leading to a new round of GWAS to discover symbiotic loci missed in the earlier phase of mapping. The primary outcomes of this project will be the identification of genes associated with the contemporary evolution of symbiosis as well as the architecture of M. truncatula genomic diversity.

This research effort will be extended by involving undergraduates from Hamline University, a four year institution located near the University of Minnesota, and from the University of Puerto Rico (UPR). Students at Hamline will work throughout the academic year and then together with UPR students during the summer as part of Minnesota's Life Sciences Summer Undergraduate Research Program (LSSURP) program. Their work will target the important but largely uncharacterized Sinorhizobial enzyme, ACC deaminase, and students will also participate in the screening of reverse genetic mutants. These experiences will provide the students the opportunity to develop their own hypothesis-driven projects. Through joint mentoring by project PIs, student training will also assist the undergraduate research program at Hamline to become more competitive for its own future external research initiatives. Genomic sequence resources will be available for public through medicagohapmap.org, and the Short Read Archive, dbSNP and FTP sites at Genbank. Importantly, the underlying Medicago Hapmap GWAS platform, available at medicagohapmap.org, will provide a long-term resource for the broader research community to discover legume genes controlling quantitative variation of agricultural and biological interest, especially trait variation in alfalfa (Medicago sativa), the fourth most widely cultivated crop in the U.S.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Legume plants play a central role in global agriculture and food security. Legumes are unique among major crops in their ability to fix atmospheric nitrogen, a trait arising from their symbiotic relationship with bacterial partners known as Sinorhizobia. Legume-rhizobial symbioses dramatically reduce the need for synthetic nitrogen fertilizer, reducing the environmental footprint of raising crops. Because of their high levels of biological nitrogen, legumes are a key source of dietary plant protein for people and animals. Together, the capacity to fix nitrogen, synthesize high levels of protein, and reduce the need for chemical fertilizer make legumes an essential foundation for sustainable agricultural systems.

To better understand the biology underlying legume-rhizobium symbioses, our NSF Plant Genome project began by validating several novel genes thought to play a role in legume nodulation, the site of symbiosis and nitrogen fixation. Previously, we discovered these candidate genes using the mapping technique, genome-wide association studies or “GWAS”. Though a powerful tool for gene discovery, GWAS typically uncovers candidates that only control a fraction of the overall nodulation phenotype, so they require extra effort to test and confirm their functional significance. For this work, our project developed a new statistically robust roadmap for testing gene function based on CRISPR gene editing technology.

 All these experiments were performed in Medicago truncatula, an excellent model for studying the biology of symbiosis. M. truncatula is closely related to alfalfa (M. sativa), a legume crop that is one of the most important forages worldwide. To expand the range of genomic tools available in Medicago, we supplemented existing genome sequences in Medicago using next generation sequencing. Our work led to the creation of several new high quality genome assemblies for different Medicago ecotypes as well as the first genome assembly for any alfalfa cultivar. These valuable genomic and bioinformatic resources are available through highly accessed websites at the University of Minnesota and the National Center for Genome Resources (NCGR). In the process, we explored the optimal strategies for integrating different next generation sequencing and physical mapping technologies, strategies that are of broad relevance to the genomics community.

Beyond the sequencing of Medicago genomes, we examined the messenger RNA “transcriptomes” of roots and nodules to learn more about the genes that play a role in symbiosis. These transcriptome sequences involved different combinations of M. truncatula accessions and Sinorhizobial strains, demonstrating that up-regulated genes during symbiosis differ across different host-symbiont combinations. We went on to use next generation sequencing to explore the genomes of microbial symbiotic partners. For this, we sequenced 200 strains of Sinorhizobia as well as the mycorrhizal fungus, Glomus, which forms a different, but equally important type of symbiosis with the roots of Medicago and other plants and is important in the uptake of phosphorous from the soil.

Our project’s research extended to the hands-on training of graduate students, post-doctorals and, undergraduates in collaboration with Hamline University, a four year undergraduate institution located in the Twin Cities. Talented Hamline undergraduates and summer research scholars recruited from under-represented institutions in Puerto Rico carried out projects to explore Sinorhizobium metabolism, bacteriophage (viruses) that infect Sinorhizobium, as well as microbial communities found in the soil surrounding legume roots. Altogether eight graduate students, seven post-doctorals and 26 undergraduates were trained as part of this Medicago genomics project. We also developed new laboratory curricula based on Medicago/Sinorhizobium to introduce undergraduates to the fascinating biology of plant-microbe interactions.
